hero.title: Understanding Medicare and Medicaid
hero.subtitle: Navigate government healthcare programs and make informed coverage decisions

content.introduction: Medicare and Medicaid are two distinct government healthcare programs that serve different populations. Medicare primarily covers individuals 65 and older, while Medicaid provides coverage for low-income individuals and families. Understanding these programs, their coverage options, and enrollment requirements is crucial for planning your healthcare in retirement or during financial hardship.
keyPoints: Medicare is primarily for people 65+ or those with certain disabilities, regardless of income
Medicaid is a need-based program for low-income individuals and families
Medicare has four parts: A (hospital), B (medical), C (Medicare Advantage), and D (prescription drugs)
Missing Medicare enrollment deadlines can result in permanent premium penalties
You can qualify for both Medicare and Medicaid simultaneously (dual eligible)

sections.title: Medicare Basics
sections.content: Medicare is a federal health insurance program primarily for people 65 and older, though younger individuals with certain disabilities or conditions (like End-Stage Renal Disease) also qualify. Most people don't pay a premium for Part A if they or their spouse paid Medicare taxes for at least 10 years. Part B requires a monthly premium (standard is $174.70 in 2024, but higher earners pay more). You're automatically enrolled in Medicare if you're receiving Social Security benefits when you turn 65. Otherwise, you need to sign up during your Initial Enrollment Period, which begins three months before your 65th birthday month and ends three months after.

sections.title: The Four Parts of Medicare
sections.content: Part A (Hospital Insurance) covers inpatient hospital stays, skilled nursing facility care, hospice, and some home health care. Part B (Medical Insurance) covers doctor visits, outpatient care, preventive services, and medical equipment. Part C (Medicare Advantage) is an alternative to Original Medicare offered by private insurers—it includes Part A and B coverage and often Part D, plus additional benefits like dental and vision. Part D (Prescription Drug Coverage) helps cover medication costs and is offered through private insurers. Most people choose either Original Medicare (Parts A and B) plus a separate Part D plan and possibly a Medigap policy, or a Medicare Advantage plan (Part C) that bundles everything.

sections.title: Medicare Costs and Coverage Gaps
sections.content: While Part A is premium-free for most, it has a deductible ($1,632 per benefit period in 2024). Part B has a $240 annual deductible and typically covers 80% of approved costs—you pay the remaining 20% with no out-of-pocket maximum. This is where Medigap (Medicare Supplement Insurance) comes in—private policies that help cover copays, coinsurance, and deductibles. Part D plans have varying premiums, deductibles, and coverage structures. Be aware of the 'donut hole'—a coverage gap where you pay more for drugs until you reach catastrophic coverage. Higher-income beneficiaries pay Income-Related Monthly Adjustment Amounts (IRMAA) for Parts B and D.

sections.title: Medicaid Basics
sections.content: Medicaid is a joint federal-state program providing health coverage to low-income individuals and families, pregnant women, children, elderly adults, and people with disabilities. Eligibility and benefits vary by state, as each state administers its own program within federal guidelines. Unlike Medicare, Medicaid typically has no or very low premiums and minimal out-of-pocket costs. Coverage is comprehensive, including hospital stays, doctor visits, long-term care, and services Medicare doesn't cover. To qualify, you must meet income and asset requirements that vary by state and category (children, pregnant women, adults, elderly, disabled).

sections.title: Dual Eligibility and Coordination
sections.content: Some individuals qualify for both Medicare and Medicaid—known as 'dual eligibles.' In these cases, Medicare is the primary payer, and Medicaid covers Medicare premiums, deductibles, and copays that the individual would otherwise have to pay. Medicaid may also cover services Medicare doesn't, like long-term nursing home care. Dual-eligible individuals can enroll in Dual Eligible Special Needs Plans (D-SNPs), Medicare Advantage plans designed specifically for this population. If you're approaching 65 and on Medicaid, you'll need to enroll in Medicare—Medicaid will help cover the costs.

sections.title: Enrollment Periods and Penalties
sections.content: Medicare's Initial Enrollment Period is crucial—missing it can result in permanent late enrollment penalties. If you don't sign up for Part B when first eligible and don't have creditable coverage (like employer insurance), you'll pay a 10% penalty for each 12-month period you were eligible but didn't enroll. Part D has a similar penalty (1% of the national base premium per month of delay). There's also an Annual Enrollment Period (October 15 - December 7) when you can change plans. For Medicaid, you can apply anytime—there's no enrollment period or penalty for late application. If you qualify, coverage typically begins the month you apply or even retroactively.

callouts.title: Enrollment Deadline Critical
callouts.content: Missing your Medicare Initial Enrollment Period can cost you thousands in permanent penalties. If you're still working at 65 with employer coverage, understand the rules—you may be able to delay Part B without penalty, but you must enroll within 8 months of leaving that job or losing coverage.

callouts.title: Medigap Open Enrollment
callouts.content: You have a 6-month Medigap Open Enrollment Period starting when you're 65 and enrolled in Part B. During this time, insurance companies can't deny you coverage or charge more due to health conditions. After this window, you may face medical underwriting and higher premiums.

callouts.title: Real-World Scenario
callouts.content: John turns 65 in June and is still working with employer health insurance. He enrolls in premium-free Part A but delays Part B since his employer coverage is creditable. When he retires at 67, he has 8 months to enroll in Part B without penalty. He chooses a Medicare Advantage plan that includes drug coverage, avoiding the need for separate Part D.

practicalSteps.title: Determine Your Eligibility
practicalSteps.description: Check if you qualify for Medicare (age 65+ or disability) or Medicaid (income-based). Visit Medicare.gov or your state's Medicaid website for specific eligibility criteria.

practicalSteps.title: Mark Your Enrollment Dates
practicalSteps.description: If approaching 65, note your Initial Enrollment Period (3 months before through 3 months after your birthday month). Set reminders to avoid late penalties.

practicalSteps.title: Evaluate Your Coverage Options
practicalSteps.description: Compare Original Medicare + Medigap + Part D versus Medicare Advantage plans. Consider your doctors, medications, and healthcare needs. Use Medicare's Plan Finder tool.

practicalSteps.title: Understand Your Costs
practicalSteps.description: Calculate total costs including premiums, deductibles, copays, and coinsurance for different plan options. Factor in IRMAA if you're a higher earner.

practicalSteps.title: Apply for Coverage
practicalSteps.description: Enroll in Medicare through Social Security (online, phone, or in person). Apply for Medicaid through your state's program. Gather necessary documents like proof of income and residency.

practicalSteps.title: Review Annually
practicalSteps.description: During the Annual Enrollment Period, review your coverage and costs. Your health needs and plan offerings change—switching plans might save money or provide better coverage.

quiz.question: What happens if you miss your Medicare Initial Enrollment Period and don't have creditable coverage?
options: Nothing, you can enroll anytime without penalty
You pay a temporary penalty for one year
You face a permanent 10% premium increase for Part B for each year delayed
quiz.explanation: Missing your Initial Enrollment Period without creditable coverage results in a permanent late enrollment penalty of 10% of the Part B premium for each 12-month period you were eligible but didn't enroll. This penalty lasts as long as you have Part B coverage.
